Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old man with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), who suffered a cardiac arrest and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a normal sinus rhythm, and his blood pressure is 145/71 mmHg.
* Neurological: The patient is unresponsive to verbal stimuli, does not follow commands, and has no motor function.
* Renal: The patient has ESRD and is on HD.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is not reported, but his arterial blood pressure is 145/71 mmHg.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 880 mL of fluid over the past 24 hours, with a net balance of -587 mL.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 6.6 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 9.0 K/uL
* Platelet count: 316 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 126 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 8.3 mg/dL
* Potassium: 4.1 mEq/L
* Sodium: 136 mEq/L
* Chloride: 98 mEq/L
* Carbon dioxide: 20.9%

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require further mechanical ventilation support.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, and he may be at risk for another cardiac event.
* Renal failure: The patient has ESRD, and his creatinine level is elevated, indicating further kidney damage.
* Seizures: The patient has a history of seizures, and he may be at risk for another seizure episode.
* Infection: The patient has a history of antibiotic use, and he may be at risk for developing an infection.

In terms of the patient's plan of care, the following steps are recommended:

* Continue mechanical ventilation support to maintain the patient's respiratory status.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and consider further cardiac monitoring.
* Continue hemodialysis to manage the patient's ESRD.
* Consider further seizure prophylaxis measures, such as increasing the dose of keppra or adding other anticonvulsants.
* Monitor the patient's laboratory results closely and adjust his treatment plan as necessary.
* Consider further antibiotics if the patient develops an infection.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Will continue today with schedule Haldol to see if any improvement in
   his mental status 5mg PO tid
   - Seroquel was also tried last night, but unsure if either the Haldol
   or the Seroquel, or increasing the Versed, has made much difference
   - F/u EKG for Haldol/Seroquel
   - Get baseline EKG for Haldol
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Had considered transfusing yesterday, will give him 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line, R PICC placed [**11-23**], and new L subclavian HD line
   placed [**11-30**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].

   could consider moving to vent rehab.

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Will continue today with schedule Haldol to see if any improvement in
   his mental status 5mg PO tid
   - Seroquel was also tried last night, but unsure if either the Haldol
   or the Seroquel, or increasing the Versed, has made much difference
   - F/u EKG for Haldol/Seroquel
   - Get baseline EKG for Haldol
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Had considered transfusing yesterday, will give him 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line, R PICC placed [**11-23**], and new L subclavian HD line
   placed [**11-30**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a previous cardiac arrest and is currently ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes. The patient has been experiencing hypertension, altered mental status, and respiratory failure. He has also had a history of fever, anemia, and labile blood pressures.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is still intubated and ventilator-dependent due to his mental status changes. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).
* Cardiovascular: The patient has hypertension and is on scheduled Labetalol.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status with agitation, thrashing around, and drooling. He has intact brainstem reflexes but is difficult to assess his cortex.
* Renal: The patient has ESRD and is on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH). His creatinine level is 8.3 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 60 mg/dL.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has diarrhea and is on a sliding scale of glucose to control his blood sugar levels.
* Infectious: The patient has a history of fever and was previously treated with antibiotics. He is currently off antibiotics and being monitored for fever.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further interventions to manage his ventilation.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypertension is being managed with Labetalol, but he may require further interventions to control his blood pressure.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's altered mental status could worsen, leading to further complications.
* Renal failure: The patient's ESRD is stable, but he may require further interventions to manage his kidney function.
* Infection: The patient's history of fever and previous antibiotic treatment may indicate an underlying infection that requires further management.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diarrhea may worsen, leading to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address his multiple medical complications. Further interventions may be necessary to stabilize his respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological status.

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now vent dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Will continue today with schedule Haldol to see if any improvement in
   his mental status 5mg PO tid
   - Seroquel was also tried last night, but unsure if either the Haldol
   or the Seroquel, or increasing the Versed, has made much difference
   - F/u EKG for Haldol/Seroquel
   - Get baseline EKG for Haldol
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Had considered transfusing yesterday, will give him 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line, R PICC placed [**11-23**], and new L subclavian HD line
   placed [**11-30**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with acute respiratory failure and hypertension. He has a history of cardiac arrest, diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to his altered mental status and respiratory failure. His vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 170s/100s mmHg, heart rate of 88 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 100% on a ventilator.

The patient's recent events include:

* Placement of a dialysis catheter on November 29
* Start of continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) on November 30
* Placement of a left subclavian HD line on November 30
* Increase in Versed drip to manage agitation and anxiety
* Start of Haldol 5mg PO tid to manage agitation
* Seroquel 50mg once given to manage agitation
* Keppra 250mg IV q12 started to manage seizures
* CVVH restarted on November 30
* Labetalol started to manage hypertension

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, but his respiratory status can deteriorate further if he develops pneumonia or other respiratory complications.
* Altered mental status: The patient's mental status has been altered since his cardiac arrest, and he is at risk of developing further cognitive decline if his sedation is weaned too quickly or if he develops seizures.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal function is end-stage, and he is dependent on dialysis. Any further decline in his renal function can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and other complications.
* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is currently elevated, and he is at risk of developing hypertensive emergencies if his blood pressure is not well-controlled.
* Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is at risk of developing further infections, particularly in his respiratory tract.
* Bleeding: The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy, and he is at risk of developing bleeding complications, particularly in his respiratory tract.
* Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, and he is at risk of developing further cardiac complications, particularly if his blood pressure is not well-controlled.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, and he is at risk of developing further gastrointestinal complications, particularly if he develops diarrhea or other gastrointestinal symptoms.

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available; need consent for procedures
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Increase haldol to 10mg tid
   - F/u EKG done today because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line
 need new art line placed today, R PICC placed

   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus (DM) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He suffered a cardiac arrest and is currently ventilator-dependent due to mental status. The patient has been experiencing hypertension, altered mental status, and respiratory failure. He has been on dialysis and has undergone several interventions, including the placement of a left subclavian HD line.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is a significant concern, with ongoing respiratory failure and the need for continued ventilator support. Weaning from the ventilator is challenging due to his agitation and copious secretions.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is a concern, with ongoing agitation and altered mental status. He is at risk for further deterioration and potential complications, including seizures and aspiration.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is severely compromised, and he is dependent on dialysis. He is at risk for further decline in renal function and potential complications, including electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.
4. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and ongoing hypertension increase his risk for further cardiovascular complications, including arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
5. Infectious Complications: The patient has a history of sepsis and is at risk for further infectious complications, including pneumonia and bacteremia.
6. Nutritional Complications: The patient's nutritional status is a concern, with ongoing tube feeding and the need for further nutrition support.
7. Hemodynamic Instability: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and he is at risk for further hemodynamic instability, including hypotension and hypertension.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust sedation and analgesia as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust dialysis settings as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust medications as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust nutrition support as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust medications as needed.
7. Consider tracheostomy and PEG placement to improve the patient's respiratory and nutritional status.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for further complications and requires ongoing close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available; need consent for procedures
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Increase haldol to 10mg tid
   - F/u EKG done today because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line
 need new art line placed today, R PICC placed
   [**11-23**], and new L subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and hypertension. He had a cardiac arrest and was intubated. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy tube in place. He has a history of chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and type II diabetes.

Recent events:

* The patient's dialysis catheter was stopped and restarted after being placed in the left subclavian line.
* He was given Haldol to manage agitation and was switched from Propofol to Versed due to triglyceride levels of 700.
* He had a staring spell that was concerning for seizures, and he was placed on continuous EEG monitoring.
* He was started on Keppra for seizure prophylaxis.
* He has been experiencing labile blood pressures, and he was started on scheduled Labetalol.
* He has been having copious secretions, which is concerning for aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to continue, and he may require ongoing mechanical ventilation.
* Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is likely to persist, and he may require ongoing sedation and analgesia.
* Seizures: The patient's history of seizures and his recent staring spell make it likely that he will continue to experience seizures, and he may require ongoing seizure prophylaxis.
* Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is likely to continue, and he may require ongoing management with antihypertensive medications.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely to continue, and he may require ongoing dialysis therapy.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and his ongoing hypertension make it likely that he will experience cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or myocardial infarction.

Recommendations:

* Continue ongoing respiratory support with mechanical ventilation.
* Continue ongoing sedation and analgesia to manage the patient's altered mental status and pain.
* Continue seizure prophylaxis with Keppra.
* Continue management of hypertension with scheduled Labetalol.
* Continue ongoing dialysis therapy to manage the patient's renal failure.
* Consider tracheostomy and PEG placement to improve the patient's nutritional status and reduce the risk of aspiration.
* Continue monitoring the patient's cardiovascular status and managing any cardiovascular complications that arise.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old man with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who suffered a cardiac arrest and is currently in respiratory failure. He is agitated and has been requiring increased sedation. He has a dialysis catheter in place and is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and pain management medications. His vital signs are stable, but he has a high risk of developing complications due to his underlying conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a major concern, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation to support his breathing.
2. Sepsis: The patient's antibiotic therapy may not be adequate to control his underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
3. Renal failure: The patient's ESRD is a significant risk factor for acute kidney injury, which could further compromise his renal function.
4. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is a significant risk factor for future cardiac events, and he may require ongoing cardiac monitoring and therapy.
5. Seizure activity: The patient's seizure activity may be a sign of underlying neurological damage or infection, which could lead to further complications.
6. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may be contributing to his cardiac arrest and respiratory failure, and he may require ongoing antihypertensive therapy.
7. Diarrhea: The patient's diarrhea may be a sign of gastrointestinal infection or inflammation, which could lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.
8. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may be a sign of underlying neurological damage or infection, which could lead to further complications.

Based on the patient's current condition and underlying medical conditions, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and trach placement should help with this.
   - IP for trach and PEG--> need to call to assure is on schedule; if not
   will ask surgery to do procedures
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
   - He is very agitated and difficult to be weaned from the vent
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Haldol to 10mg tid
   - Seroquel can be added because QTc was normal
   - F/u EKG done today because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   .

   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Chest xray this morning
   - re pan culture this morning
   - add abios if he has CXR
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - On  Epogen with HD
   - Transfused 1U PRBC's
   - Will continue to monitor
   .
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Continue on PRN IV labetalol because pressures are labile and cannot
   prescribe standing dose.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   .
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal) NPO
   for placement
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: ART line placed [**12-1**], R PICC placed [**11-23**], and new L
   subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus (DM) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, was intubated, and is currently ventilator-dependent. The patient has several active issues, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and ventilator-dependent due to mental status and agitation, which makes it difficult to wean him from the ventilator.
2. Altered mental status: The patient has intact brainstem reflexes but is agitated and not following commands, making it challenging to assess his cortex.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's renal function is unstable, and he requires continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH).
4. Fever: The patient has had a long course of antibiotics for a positive urine culture, and he is currently on Linezolid for purulent appearing central venous lines (CVL).
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is chronic and stable, and he is receiving Epogen with hemodialysis (HD).
6. Labile blood pressures: The patient has been intermittently hypotensive and hypertensive, and he is currently on scheduled Labetalol.
7. RUE swelling: The patient has swelling in his right upper extremity (RUE) due to a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein, which requires a procedure prior to PICC removal.

Potential medical complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for developing VAP due to his prolonged intubation and mechanical ventilation.
2. Aspiration: The patient's copious secretions and altered mental status make him at risk for aspiration if he is weaned from the ventilator.
3. Sepsis: The patient's fever and purulent appearing CVL make him at risk for developing sepsis.
4. Renal failure: The patient's unstable renal function and need for CVVH make him at risk for further renal deterioration.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's labile blood pressures and need for electrolyte replacement make him at risk for developing electrolyte imbalances.
6. Hypoglycemia: The patient's DM and need for sliding scale insulin make him at risk for developing hypoglycemia.
7. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's RUE swelling and thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein make him at risk for developing a pulmonary embolism.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his multiple medical issues to prevent complications and promote recovery.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.

    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with

   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and trach placement should help with this.
   - IP for trach and PEG--> need to call to assure is on schedule
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
   - He is very agitated and difficult to be weaned from the vent
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Increase haldol to 10mg tid
   - F/u EKG done today because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
   .
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   .
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS

s, will continue to cover with SSI only

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and Acute Renal Failure (ARF). He had a PEA arrest and was intubated. He is currently ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes.

Active issues:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's agitation is a major hindrance to weaning from the ventilator. He has copious secretions, which is concerning for aspiration.
2. Altered mental status: The patient has intact brainstem reflexes but has difficulty assessing his cortex. He has been making some progress towards improvement but has recently become agitated and non-responsive.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's etiology of ARF is unclear, and he is unlikely to regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Pneumonia: The patient has bibasilar atelectasis and possible PNA on CT chest.
2. Aspiration: The patient's copious secretions and agitation increase the risk of aspiration.
3. Seizures: The patient has had a staring spell and has been on continuous EEG with epileptiform spikes.
4. Hypertension: The patient has labile blood pressures and is on scheduled Labetalol.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient has had issues with hyponatremia in the past and continues to be monitored.
6. Hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia: The patient has elevated PTH and hypercalcemia, which may be secondary or tertiary due to renal failure.
7. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with collaterals and needs a plasty prior to PICC removal.
8. Dialysis catheter-related complications: The patient has a new L subclavian HD line placed, and the previous line was removed due to purulent appearing CVL.

The patient requires continued close monitoring and management of his respiratory, neurological, and renal status. He also needs ongoing management of his blood pressure, electrolytes, and glucose control.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old man who remains critically ill in the ICU following cardiac arrest. He is still agitated and requires heavy sedation. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 96 bpm, and blood pressure of 145/76 mmHg. He is mechanically ventilated with a FiO2 of 40% and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. His respiratory support is complicated by poor lung mechanics, with a RSBI of 32.

The patient has a history of respiratory failure, end-stage renal disease, and cardiac arrest. He is also experiencing hypertension, diarrhea, and altered mental status. His laboratory results show anemia, elevated troponin-T, and abnormal liver enzymes.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's poor lung mechanics and need for high levels of oxygen may increase the risk of respiratory failure.
2. Infection: The patient's altered mental status and diarrhea may increase the risk of infection.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated troponin-T and abnormal liver enzymes may indicate sepsis.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and elevated troponin-T may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
5. Renal complications: The patient's end-stage renal disease may increase the risk of renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or electrolyte imbalances.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diarrhea may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as dehydration or electrolyte imbalances.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may increase the risk of neurological complications, such as seizures or cerebral edema.
8. Bleeding complications: The patient's abnormal liver enzymes and elevated troponin-T may increase the risk of bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG
   yesterday
   - Low grade fevers, secretions on L, L lobe collapse, gm (+) cocci and
   GNR--> start VAP treatment with cefipime, linezolid, and cipro
   - weaning sedation in now that using PO haldol and seroquel.  Has been
   tolerating decrease in midaz by 2 and fentanyl by 25 every shift.  Will
   stop haldol and increase seroquel to 75 TID.
   - add methadone 10mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl.
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Weaning his drip sedations now that treating with haldol and
   seroquel.
   - F/u EKG daily because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Will get HD today and a unit of pRBC
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Start antibiotics as above.
   - tylenol
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - EPO at HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
   - guaiac stools
   - continue to monitor and consider hemolytic w/u in future
    .
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive.  Had to
   start labetalol drip last night because could not control BP.  Stop
   drip for HD and reassess after HD session
   - Keep watching pressures
   - Try to restart home labetalol 600mg [**Hospital1 **] after HD
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line
 need new art line placed today, R PICC placed
   [**11-23**], and new L subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG
   yesterday
   - Low grade fevers, secretions on L, L lobe collapse, gm (+) cocci and
   GNR--> start VAP treatment with cefipime, linezolid, and cipro
   - weaning sedation in now that using PO haldol and seroquel.  Has been
   tolerating decrease in midaz by 2 and fentanyl by 25 every shift.  Will
   stop haldol and increase seroquel to 75 TID.
   - add methadone 10mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl.
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Weaning his drip sedations now that treating with haldol and
   seroquel.
   - F/u EKG daily because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Will get HD today and a unit of pRBC
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Start antibiotics as above.
   - tylenol
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - EPO at HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
   - guaiac stools
   - continue to monitor and consider hemolytic w/u in future
    .
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive.  Had to
   start labetalol drip last night because could not control BP.  Stop
   drip for HD and reassess after HD session
   - Keep watching pressures
   - Try to restart home labetalol 600mg [**Hospital1 **] after HD
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease. He suffered a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and was intubated. He is currently ventilator-dependent due to mental status. The patient has several active issues, including respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute on chronic renal failure, fever, anemia, and labile blood pressures.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and weaning from the ventilator is challenging due to his agitation. He may require a tracheostomy to improve his respiratory status.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is a concern, and weaning from sedation is difficult. He may require further neurological evaluation to determine the cause of his mental status changes.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is a significant concern, and he may require further evaluation to determine the cause of his renal failure. He may require dialysis, and his electrolyte levels need to be closely monitored.
4. Fever: The patient's fever is a concern, and he may require further evaluation to determine the cause of his fever. He may require antibiotics, and his temperature needs to be closely monitored.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is a concern, and he may require further evaluation to determine the cause of his anemia. He may require blood transfusions, and his hemoglobin levels need to be closely monitored.
6. Labile Blood Pressures: The patient's labile blood pressures are a concern, and he may require further evaluation to determine the cause of his blood pressure fluctuations. He may require medications to control his blood pressure.
7. HypoNa: The patient's hyponatremia is a concern, and he may require further evaluation to determine the cause of his hyponatremia. He may require medications to correct his electrolyte imbalance.
8. Endo: The patient's elevated PTH is a concern, and he may require further evaluation to determine the cause of his PTH elevation. He may require medications to correct his electrolyte imbalance.
9. RUE Swelling: The patient's RUE swelling is a concern, and he may require further evaluation to determine the cause of his swelling. He may require further imaging studies to determine the cause of his swelling.
10. DM Type II: The patient's DM type II is a concern, and he may require further evaluation to determine the cause of his hyperglycemia. He may require medications to control his blood sugar levels.

Overall, the patient has several active issues that require close monitoring and management. He may require further evaluation and treatment to address these issues and improve his overall health.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG
   yesterday
   - Low grade fevers, secretions on L, L lobe collapse, gm (+) cocci and
   GNR--> start VAP treatment with cefipime, vanc, and cipro
   - weaning sedation in now that using PO haldol and seroquel.  Has been
   tolerating decrease in midaz by 2 and fentanyl by 25 every shift
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Weaning his drip sedations now that treating with haldol and
   seroquel.
   - F/u EKG daily because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Will get HD today and a unit of pRBC
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Start antibiotics as above.
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - EPO at HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
   - guaiac stools
   - hemolytic w/u: haptoglpobin, smear, tbili, ibili, and fibrinogen
    .
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive.  Had to
   start labetalol drip last night because could not control BP.  Stop
   drip for HD and reassess after HD session
   - Keep watching pressures
   - Add labetalol as need this afternoon
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI

 need new art line placed today, R PICC placed
