   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   # New spiking fevers, hypotension: Infection (recent sputum with
   Micrococcus and now with positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood
   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed).
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl.
   - CT with contrast to investigate possible abdominal process; renal ok
   with IV and po contrast, given graft failure
   - Continue Bactrim; confirm dosing with ID or pharmacy
   - f/u C. diff and fungal cultures
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - Monitor status of possible sinus infection given current clinical
   improvement and active drainage
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures --> discuss
   with Neuro
   - no beta-blockers
   - Wean off Levophed as tolerated
   - Add on beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and prednisone)
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG placed
   on [**12-2**].
   - d/c Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation and attempt to wean from
   vent
   - Decrease Methadone by
 dose but ?withdrawal so increased back to
   10mg tid.  Consider slow taper.
   - Pressure support trial today.
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Continue weaning sedation, as above.
   - Have added methadone 10mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl; wean
   to 7.5mg tid; wean to half dose (11mg daily).
   - F/u EKG daily because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Doesn't appear to be DIC, or hemolysis
   - EPO at HD
   - Guiac stools
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - HD yesterday; HD vs. CVVH tomorrow
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - AlOH discontinued previously
   - On Renagel 800 tid.  D/C Sevelemer and initiate Amphagel.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive.
   - Keep watching pressures
   - Hold Labetalol for low bp's and give prn for elevated bp's.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - Increase ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, discontinue famotidine and instead
   start sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a prolonged course of Cefepime for a positive urine culture (UCx) and was recently started on Linezolid for purulent appearing central venous line (CVL) bilaterally. He developed a fever, hypertension, and altered mental status, and was intubated for respiratory failure. He has a history of chronic anemia, diabetes mellitus type II, and hypertension.

The patient's current status is:

* Fever: Spiking fevers, currently on Bactrim IV
* Hypertension: Benign, currently on Nitro drip and Labetalol
* Altered mental status: Agitated, responding to verbal stimuli, with intact brainstem reflexes
* Respiratory failure: Ventilator-dependent due to mental status
* Anemia: Chronic and stable, possibly related to renal disease
* Acute renal failure: Unlikely to regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis
* Labile blood pressures: Hypertensive, currently on Labetalol
* Endo: Elevated PTH, hypercalcemic, and hyperphosphatemic
* RUE swelling: Thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with +collaterals

Potential medical complications:

* Infection: The patient's recent sputum cultures showed coag-positive Staph aureus and Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both of which are sensitive to Bactrim. The patient's fevers may be due to an infectious source.
* Hemolytic reaction to blood transfusion: The patient received 1 unit of blood transfusion yesterday, and his normal haptoglobin levels reduce the likelihood of hemolytic reaction. However, febrile transfusion reaction is still possible.
* TTP: The patient's recent symptoms, including fever, hypertension, and altered mental status, could be related to TTP.
* Abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm: The patient's recent CT scan showed diffuse mesenteric stranding with no small or large bowel pathology identified.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient had a recent PEA arrest, and his current hypertension may be related to this event.
* Renal failure: The patient's ARF is likely to continue, and he may require ongoing dialysis.

Recommendations:

* Continue Bactrim IV for the patient's fever
* Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust Labetalol as needed
* Wean the patient off sedation and attempt to extubate
* Consider tracheostomy and PEG placement
* Continue dialysis and adjust medications as necessary
* Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust medications as necessary
* Consider adding beta-glucan and galactomannan to the patient's treatment regimen
* F/u with Heme Onc about the patient's smear and looking for shistos
* Continue Keppra for the patient's possible subclinical seizures

s/100

   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed).
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl.
   - CT with contrast to investigate possible abdominal process; renal ok
   with IV and po contrast, given graft failure
   - Continue Bactrim; confirm dosing with ID or pharmacy
   - f/u C. diff and fungal cultures
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - Monitor status of possible sinus infection given current clinical
   improvement and active drainage
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - no beta-blockers
   - Wean off Levophed as tolerated
   - Add on beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and prednisone)
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG placed
   on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation, d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam
   sedation.
   - Attempt to wean from vent
   - Decrease Methadone by
 dose but ?withdrawal so increased back to
   10mg tid.  Consider slow taper.
   - Pressure support trial today.
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   - Continue Keppra 250mg IV q12h for now, will discuss with Neuro
   - Continue weaning sedation, as above.
   - methadone 10mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl; wean to slowly
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.

   - 2 units PRBC per Renal recs

   - EPO at HD
   - Guiac stools
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - HD yesterday; HD vs. CVVH possibly today pending renal recs
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - AlOH discontinued previously
   - On Renagel 800 tid.  D/C Sevelemer and initiate Amphagel.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following

   setting of tachy and hypertensive.

   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - Increase ISS

   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, discontinue famotidine and instead
   start sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now

   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He has a history of chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. He was intubated due to respiratory failure and has been on mechanical ventilation since admission. He has developed a fever, hypertension, and altered mental status, which is concerning for infection, sepsis, or other complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, hypertension, and altered mental status suggest that he may be developing sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, as it may lead to further complications, such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or respiratory arrest.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's ESRD is a significant risk factor for further renal failure, which may lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and other complications.
4. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's hypertension and cardiac arrest history increase his risk for cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction, cardiac arrhythmias, or cardiac arrest.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's altered mental status and seizures suggest that he may be at risk for further neurological complications, such as cerebral edema, brain herniation, or status epilepticus.
6. Infection: The patient's positive sputum cultures and fevers suggest that he may have a serious infection, which requires prompt treatment to prevent further complications.
7. Hemolytic Reaction: The patient's recent blood transfusion and positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT) suggest that he may be at risk for a hemolytic reaction, which can be life-threatening.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's recent abdominal surgery and positive stool cultures suggest that he may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation, abscess, or sepsis.
9. Thrombotic Complications: The patient's recent thrombotic events, including DVT and pulmonary embolism, suggest that he may be at risk for further thrombotic complications, such as stroke, myocardial infarction, or pulmonary embolism.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation.
2. Administer antibiotics to treat the patient's suspected infection.
3. Continue to provide mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to support the patient's respiratory function.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and electrolyte levels to prevent further complications.
5. Consider transferring the patient to a higher level of care, such as an intensive care unit (ICU), to provide more comprehensive monitoring and treatment.
6. Consider performing further diagnostic tests, such as imaging studies or blood cultures, to determine the cause of the patient's infection and to guide treatment.
7. Consider administering stress-dose corticosteroids to prevent adrenal insufficiency.
8. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust his insulin regimen as needed to prevent hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.
9. Consider administering anticoagulation therapy to prevent further thrombotic complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old man who suffered a cardiac arrest and is currently in the ICU. He has been experiencing poor mental status (MS) and became agitated and diaphoretic overnight. His fever has been treated with antibiotics, and his respiratory failure is being managed with mechanical ventilation. He has also been experiencing hypertension, diarrhea, altered mental status, and renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and altered mental status suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a critical condition that requires close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention and management to prevent further complications.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is a critical condition that requires close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration.
5. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is a potential complication that requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.
6. Diarrhea: The patient's diarrhea is a potential complication that requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.
7. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is a potential complication that requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.
8. Sternal wound infection: The patient's cardiac arrest and respiratory failure increase the risk of sternal wound infection, which can lead to serious complications.
9. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and altered mental status increase the risk of pneumonia, which can lead to serious complications.
10. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobility and respiratory failure increase the risk of DVT, which can lead to serious complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.
   - Attempt to wean from vent
   - Decrease Methadone by
 dose but ?withdrawal so increased back to
   10mg tid.  Consider slow taper.
   - Pressure support trial did not go well last night.  Was not pulling
   the volumes needed and was tachypneic
   - Return to seroquel PRN
   .
   # New spiking fevers, hypotension: Infection (recent sputum with
   Micrococcus and now with positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood
   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed).
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.
   - CT with contrast to investigate possible abdominal process; renal ok
   with IV and po contrast, given graft failure
   - Continue Bactrim; confirm dosing with ID or pharmacy
   - f/u C. diff and fungal cultures
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - Monitor status of possible sinus infection given current clinical
   improvement and active drainage
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - no beta-blockers
   - Add on beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and prednisone)
     # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
   - Labetalol drip with low dose po Labetalol for goal BP ~150 given
   tenuous BP status.
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   - Continue Keppra 250mg IV q12h for now, will discuss with Neuro
   - Continue weaning sedation, as above.
   - methadone 10mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl; wean to slowly
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - HD Friday and assess need for blood products at this time.
   - Doesn't appear to be DIC, or hemolysis
   - EPO at HD
   - Guiac stools
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - HD yesterday; HD vs. CVVH possibly today pending renal recs
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - AlOH discontinued previously
   - On Renagel 800 tid.  D/C Sevelemer and initiate Amphagel.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, discontinue famotidine and instead
   start sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.

ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with a complex medical history, including end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, diabetes mellitus (DM), and chronic kidney disease. He was admitted to the ICU with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF) and has since developed multiple medical complications.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent due to mental status and has a history of possible pneumonia, although the diagnosis is unclear.
2. Infection: The patient has developed a new spiking fever and has a positive sputum culture for Staphylococcus aureus and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia. He is currently receiving Bactrim IV for treatment.
3. Hemodynamic instability: The patient has had labile blood pressures, ranging from hypotensive to hypertensive, and is receiving Labetalol for control.
4. Altered mental status: The patient has had intermittent periods of agitation and confusion, with intact brainstem reflexes but difficulty assessing his cortex.
5. Anemia: The patient has chronic and stable anemia, with possible causes including ACD, renal disease, or B12 and folate deficiency.
6. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient has developed acute ARF, with unclear etiology, and is currently receiving hemodialysis (HD) and continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).
7. Other issues: The patient has also developed ST elevations on his EKG, which have resolved, and has had issues with hyponatremia, which have resolved. He has also had elevated PTH and hypercalcemia, which are likely secondary to renal failure.

The potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's infection could worsen and lead to sepsis, which could further compromise his respiratory and cardiovascular function.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen, leading to increased respiratory distress and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's labile blood pressures and history of hypertension could lead to cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status could worsen, leading to increased agitation, confusion, and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's anemia could worsen, leading to hemorrhagic complications, such as bleeding diathesis or gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Renal complications: The patient's acute ARF could worsen, leading to further kidney damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Infectious complications: The patient's infection could spread to other parts of his body, leading to further complications and potentially life-threatening outcomes.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, infection, hemodynamic instability, altered mental status, anemia, and acute on chronic renal failure. The potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions are numerous and could have significant consequences for the patient's outcome.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.
   - Attempt to wean from vent
   - Decrease Methadone by
 dose but ?withdrawal so increased back to
   10mg tid.  Consider slow taper.
   - Pressure support trial did not go well last night.  Was not pulling
   the volumes needed and was tachypneic
   - Return to seroquel PRN
   .
   # New spiking fevers, hypotension: Infection (recent sputum with
   Micrococcus and now with positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood
   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed).
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.
   - CT with contrast to investigate possible abdominal process; renal ok
   with IV and po contrast, given graft failure
   - Continue Bactrim; confirm dosing with ID or pharmacy
   - f/u C. diff and fungal cultures
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - Monitor status of possible sinus infection given current clinical
   improvement and active drainage
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - no beta-blockers
   - Add on beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and prednisone)
     # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
   - Labetalol drip with low dose po Labetalol for goal BP ~150 given
   tenuous BP status.
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   - Continue Keppra 250mg IV q12h for now, will discuss with Neuro
   - Continue weaning sedation, as above.
   - methadone 10mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl; wean to slowly
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - HD Friday and assess need for blood products at this time.
   .
   - Doesn't appear to be DIC, or hemolysis
   - EPO at HD
   - Guiac stools
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - HD yesterday; HD vs. CVVH possibly today pending renal recs
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - AlOH discontinued previously
   - On Renagel 800 tid.  D/C Sevelemer and initiate Amphagel.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, discontinue famotidine and instead
   start sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with a complex medical history, including ESRD, HTN, DM, and a recent PEA arrest. The patient is currently ventilator-dependent and has been diagnosed with pneumonia, with a positive sputum culture showing coag-positive Staph aureus and Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
* Infection: The patient has a positive sputum culture, and the ID recommends continuing Bactrim.
* Fever: The patient has had spiking fevers, and the cause is unclear, with possible sources including infection, blood transfusion reaction, drug reaction, TTP, or abdominal perforation.
* Altered mental status: The patient has intact brainstem reflexes but has difficulty assessing his cortex, with agitation and thrashing around when sedation is weaned.
* Anemia: The patient has chronic and stable anemia, with possible causes including ACD or renal disease.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, with unclear etiology, and is currently on dialysis.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Seizures: The patient has a history of seizures and is currently on Keppra, which may need to be adjusted or changed.
* Infection: The patient has a positive sputum culture and may be at risk for further infections, particularly with coag-positive Staph aureus.
* Bleeding: The patient has a history of bleeding and may be at risk for further bleeding, particularly with the use of anticoagulants.
* Hypotension: The patient has had episodes of hypotension and may be at risk for further episodes, particularly with the use of vasodilators.
* Hypercalcemia: The patient has hypercalcemia and may be at risk for further episodes, particularly with the use of calcium supplements.
* Hyperphosphatemia: The patient has hyperphosphatemia and may be at risk for further episodes, particularly with the use of phosphate binders.
* Endo: The patient has elevated PTH and may be at risk for further episodes, particularly with the use of anticonvulsants.
* RUE swelling: The patient has RUE swelling and may be at risk for further episodes, particularly with the use of anticoagulants.
* DM type II: The patient has DM type II and may be at risk for further episodes, particularly with the use of insulin.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Ventilator support
* Antibiotics for pneumonia
* Keppra for seizures
* Sedation for agitation
* Dialysis for acute on chronic renal failure
* Anticonvulsants for seizures
* Anticoagulants for bleeding
* Vasodilators for hypertension
* Calcium and phosphate supplements for hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia
* Anticonvulsants for endo
* Anticoagulants for RUE swelling
* Insulin for DM type II

The patient's current status is critical, and close monitoring is necessary to address potential complications and adjust treatment as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 62-year-old male who is critically ill and has been admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure. He has a history of failed renal transplant, PEA arrest, and respiratory failure. The patient has been experiencing fever, hypertension, and diarrhea, and is currently receiving treatment for these conditions. He is also being treated for acute respiratory failure, which is being managed with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a critical concern, and the risk of further deterioration is high. The patient's oxygen saturation is 99%, but his respiratory rate is 15 breaths per minute, which may indicate respiratory muscle fatigue.
2. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is a significant concern, and the risk of cardiac complications is high. The patient's blood pressure is 99/50 mmHg, which is above the normal range.
3. Fever: The patient's fever is a potential source of infection, and the risk of sepsis is high. The patient's temperature is 101.7°F, which is above the normal range.
4. Diarrhea: The patient's diarrhea is a potential source of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. The patient's stool output is not specified, but the risk of dehydration is high.
5. Renal Failure: The patient's renal failure is a critical concern, and the risk of further deterioration is high. The patient's creatinine level is 6.4 mg/dL, which is above the normal range.
6. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is a critical concern, and the risk of further cardiac complications is high.
7. Sepsis: The patient's fever and respiratory failure increase the risk of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure.
8. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient's respiratory failure and prolonged use of the ventilator increase the risk of VAP, which can lead to further respiratory complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust therapy as needed to prevent further deterioration.
2. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension with antihypertensive medications and monitor blood pressure closely.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's fever and consider empiric antibiotic therapy if the fever persists or worsens.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's diarrhea and stool output and consider IV fluids and electrolyte replacement if necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and consider dialysis if necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider further cardiac testing if necessary.
7. Consider further diagnostic testing, such as blood cultures and imaging studies, to identify the underlying cause of the patient's respiratory failure and fever.
8. Consider consults with infectious disease and cardiology specialists to optimize the patient's care.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis.
   - Trach mask again today
   - Decrease Methadone to 5 today x 3 days and begin to wean
   - Return to zyprexa PRN
   .
   # Spiking fevers, hypotension: Infection (recent sputum with
   Micrococcus and now with positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood
   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed). No fevers overnight
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.
   - Continue Bactrim until [**2107-12-15**]
   - f/u C. diff and fungal cultures
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - no beta-blockers
   - Add on beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and prednisone)
     # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
   - d/c labetalol drip and change PO labetalol dose to 800 TID from 600
   TID
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   - Continue Keppra 250mg IV q12h for now, will discuss with Neuro
   - Continue weaning sedation, as above.
   - methadone 5mg TID to assist with weaning from narcotic dependence
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis
   - HD Friday and assess need for blood products at this time.
   - EPO at HD
   - Guiac stools
   .
   DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels including
   his IVC.  He is on a heparin drip and being bridged with coumadin
   - Daily INR
   - Coumadin 5mg PO daily
   - D/c heparin drip when has been therapeutic (INR between [**2-8**] for 24
   hours).  Ok to go to rehab on heparin drip.
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - HD MWF
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - On Renagel 800 tid.
   - Started Sevelemer 30.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, discontinue famotidine and instead
   start sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: pending rehab placement if can wean from vent.  [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 273**]
   [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] working on placement.

   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - HD MWF
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - On Renagel 800 tid.
   - Started Sevelemer 30.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, discontinue famotidine and instead
   start sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: pending rehab placement if can wean from vent.  [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 273**]
   [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] working on placement.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a prolonged course of antibiotics, including cefepime and linezolid, for a positive urine culture (UCx) and was recently intubated due to mental status changes and respiratory failure. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease. He had a cardiac arrest and was resuscitated, and now requires mechanical ventilation.

Current Status:

The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is being weaned off sedation. His mental status is altered, and he is experiencing agitation and thrashing around. He has intact brainstem reflexes but has difficulty assessing his cortex.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he requires mechanical ventilation. Weaning from the ventilator may be challenging due to his altered mental status and respiratory acidosis.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of infections, including pneumonia and sepsis, and is at risk for further infections due to his immunocompromised state.
3. Bleeding: The patient has a coagulopathy due to his renal disease and is at risk for bleeding, particularly with invasive procedures such as central line placement.
4. Anemia: The patient has chronic anemia due to his renal disease, and his anemia may worsen due to his ongoing bleeding and transfusion requirements.
5. DVT: The patient has a history of DVT and is at risk for further thrombotic events due to his immobility and underlying medical conditions.
6. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is unstable, and he requires ongoing dialysis to manage his electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.
7. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and he is at risk for further hypertensive episodes due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.
8. Seizures: The patient has a history of seizures and is at risk for further seizure activity due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and weaning from sedation to improve respiratory status.
2. Monitor the patient's mental status closely and consider EEG monitoring to rule out seizure activity.
3. Continue antibiotics and antifungal medications to treat potential infections.
4. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and consider platelet transfusions if necessary.
5. Continue dialysis and monitor the patient's electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.
6. Consider stress dose steroids if the patient's blood pressure becomes unstable.
7. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider blood transfusions if necessary.
8. Consider anticoagulation therapy to prevent further thrombotic events.
9. Monitor the patient's blood pressure closely and consider medications to control hypertension.
10. Consider EEG monitoring and anticonvulsant medications to manage seizure activity.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now

   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis.
   - Trach mask again today
   - Decrease Methadone to 7.5 today x 3 days and begin to wean
   - Return to zyprexa PRN
   .
   # spiking fevers, hypotension: Infection (recent sputum with
   Micrococcus and now with positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood
   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed).
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.
   - CT with contrast to investigate possible abdominal process; renal ok
   with IV and po contrast, given graft failure
   - Continue Bactrim; confirm dosing with ID or pharmacy
   - f/u C. diff and fungal cultures
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - no beta-blockers
   - Add on beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and prednisone)
     # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
   - Labetalol drip with low dose po Labetalol for goal BP ~150 given
   tenuous BP status.
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   - Continue Keppra 250mg IV q12h for now, will discuss with Neuro
   - Continue weaning sedation, as above.
   - methadone 7.5mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl; wean to slowly
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - HD Friday and assess need for blood products at this time.
   .
   - Doesn't appear to be DIC, or hemolysis
   - EPO at HD
   - Guiac stools
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - HD yesterday; HD vs. CVVH possibly today pending renal recs
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - AlOH discontinued previously
   - On Renagel 800 tid.  D/C Sevelemer and initiate Amphagel.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, discontinue famotidine and instead
   start sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.

   - methadone 7.5mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl; wean to slowly
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - HD Friday and assess need for blood products at this time.
   .
   - Doesn't appear to be DIC, or hemolysis
   - EPO at HD
   - Guiac stools
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - HD yesterday; HD vs. CVVH possibly today pending renal recs
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - AlOH discontinued previously
   - On Renagel 800 tid.  D/C Sevelemer and initiate Amphagel.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, discontinue famotidine and instead
   start sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a cardiac arrest and was intubated. He is currently ventilator-dependent and has been experiencing spiking fevers, hypotension, and altered mental status. He has a history of chronic and stable anemia, and his acute on chronic renal failure is unclear. He has been receiving hemodialysis (HD) and continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient has been experiencing spiking fevers, hypotension, and altered mental status, which may be due to an underlying infection. The patient has a history of pneumonia and has been receiving antibiotics.
2. Blood Transfusion Reaction: The patient received a blood transfusion yesterday and has been experiencing fevers and hypotension, which may be due to a blood transfusion reaction.
3. Drug Reaction: The patient has been receiving several medications, including antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and sedatives, which may be causing the patient's symptoms.
4. TTP (Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura): The patient has been experiencing thrombocytopenia and is at risk for TTP.
5. Abdominal Perforation: The patient has a history of abdominal surgery and has been experiencing abdominal pain, which may be due to an abdominal perforation.
6. Lactic Acidosis: The patient has been experiencing lactic acidosis, which may be due to his underlying medical conditions or the medications he is receiving.
7. Hypoglycemia: The patient has been experiencing hypoglycemia, which may be due to his diabetes and the medications he is receiving.
8. Hypertension: The patient has been experiencing hypertension, which may be due to his underlying medical conditions or the medications he is receiving.
9. Hypotension: The patient has been experiencing hypotension, which may be due to his underlying medical conditions or the medications he is receiving.
10. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently ventilator-dependent and may be at risk for respiratory failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to assess for any changes in his condition.
2. Continue to administer antibiotics and anticonvulsants as prescribed.
3. Consider adding a second antibiotic to the patient's regimen to cover for any potential bacterial infections.
4. Monitor the patient's platelet count and consider administering platelet transfusions if necessary.
5. Consider administering fresh frozen plasma to the patient to help manage his coagulopathy.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's abdominal pain and consider performing an abdominal ultrasound to rule out any potential abdominal perforations.
7. Consider administering lactic acidosis treatment to the patient if his lactic acid levels continue to rise.
8. Monitor the patient's glucose levels and consider administering glucose supplements if necessary.
9. Consider administering antihypertensive medications to the patient to help manage his hypertension.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider performing a respiratory function test to assess for any changes in his lung function.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus (DM) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a prolonged course of antibiotics for a positive culture, including Cefepime and Linezolid, and was recently transitioned to Bactrim.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is ventilator-dependent due to altered mental status and respiratory failure. He had a tracheostomy and PEG placement on [**12-2**].
* Cardiovascular: He has labile blood pressures, with episodes of hypertension and hypotension. He was transitioned from Labetalol drip to oral Labetalol tid.
* Neurological: He has altered mental status, with intact brainstem reflexes but difficulty assessing his cortex. He was previously on sedation, but it was weaned off due to triglycerides of 700. He has been on Keppra for possible subclinical seizures.
* Renal: He has acute on chronic renal failure, and his etiology of ARF is unclear. He is on hemodialysis (HD) three times a week and is being bridged with Coumadin.
* Infectious: He has a positive culture for Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, which is sensitive to Bactrim. He has also had a positive culture for Micrococcus and coag-positive Staph aureus.
* Gastrointestinal: He has diarrhea and is on tube feeds (Novasource Renal).
* Hematological: He has anemia, with a recent decrease in hemoglobin.
* Other: He has a DVT in several vessels, including his IVC, and is on a heparin drip. He has also had a history of hypertension, hypercalcemia, and hyperphosphatemia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient had emesis during morning rounds and aspirated tube feeds, which could lead to aspiration pneumonia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent and has a history of respiratory failure, which could worsen if not managed properly.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a positive culture for multiple organisms, which could lead to sepsis if not treated promptly.
4. Hemolytic reaction to blood transfusion: The patient received a blood transfusion recently, and his normal haptoglobin reduces the likelihood of hemolytic reaction, but febrile transfusion reaction is still possible.
5. Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, and his etiology of ARF is unclear. He is on HD three times a week, but his renal function may worsen if not managed properly.
6. DVT: The patient has a DVT in several vessels, including his IVC, which could lead to pulmonary embolism if not managed properly.
7. Hypertension: The patient has labile blood pressures, which could worsen if not managed properly.
8. Hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia: The patient has a history of hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, which could worsen if not managed properly.
9. Seizures: The patient has been on Keppra for possible subclinical seizures, but seizures could still occur if not managed properly.

To manage these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and treatment by a multidisciplinary team, including intensivists, nephrologists, infectious disease specialists, and other healthcare professionals.

   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis.
   - Trach mask again today
   - Decrease Methadone to 5 today x 3 days and begin to wean
   - Return to zyprexa PRN
   .
   # Spiking fevers, hypotension: Infection (recent sputum with
   Micrococcus and now with positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood
   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed). No fevers overnight
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.
   - Continue Bactrim until [**2107-12-15**]

   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - no beta-blockers
   - Add on beta-glucan and galactomannan
